awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Ecohydrology of Tropical Montane Forests -- Diversity in Science, Interdisciplinary Breadth, and Global Awareness
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU site will support eight students per year, recruited from 2-year community colleges, to participate in a 10-week international research experience. The participants will characterize the gradient of water, climate, and biodiversity in the watershed of a tropical montane forest in central Costa Rica under the guidance of Texas A&M University faculty from the Colleges of Agriculture and Life Sciences, Civil Engineering, and Geosciences, alongside faculty and students at institutions in Costa Rica. Students utilize natural climate gradients from lowland rainforests to high-elevation cloud forests to characterize land-atmosphere interactions and processes that impact streamflow generation. The program is designed to provide crosscutting understanding of the interactions among biophysical processes, water management, and human impacts in a regional-to-global context. Activities provide a firsthand international research experience, foster a learning community, demonstrate the foundational importance of diversity in science, provide students with a cultural experience, and increase awareness of the interconnection between forests, water and people.  

Recruitment strategies to enhance participation of students from diverse backgrounds include visiting target schools, making the website more attractive to a wide range of applicants, providing resources and assistance in the application process, and breaking down barriers to participate in study abroad programs. The assessment team will examine how those mentoring experiences encourage students to understand the scientific research process, develop individual research interests, and appreciate their mentoring experiences with faculty members. The expected outcomes include joint faculty-student publications in leading research journals, research conference presentations, and studies to assess the success of international field experiences.

Recent evidence suggests that projected temperature increases over land and sea will lead to decreased cloud cover and altered precipitation regimes in Central America. Deforestation of lowland rainforest can further reduce cloud and mist, which amplifies drought, alters forest structure, and reduces stream flows crucial for dry-season water supplies to downstream users. REU students will observe how water from the mountains affects agriculture and society in the valley below via cultural exchanges and service learning projects that provide them with global competences including the ability to live and work effectively in a diverse and global society, and articulate the value of a diverse and global perspective.

This site is supported by the Department of Defense in partnership with the NSF REU program

por.por_cntn:
This REU site project -- a.k.a., the Texas A&M Costa Rica REU -- hosted a total of 28 students (27 funded by NSF) in the summers of 2018, 2019, 2020, and 2021. The program provided a firsthand international research experience for undergraduate students within the pre-montane forest at the Texas A&M University Soltis Center for Research and Education, other research stations within Costa Rica, and on the Texas A&M campus.

Ecohydrology provided a unifying theme that was deepened by emphasis on "diversity in science" and "interdisciplinary breadth" -- students' majors and faculty mentors' specialties spanned a wide spectrum across geosciences, engineering, agriculture and life sciences, and public policy. Students represented broadly defined diversity across many other indicators -- e.g., 20 states and Guam were represented, and 30% of students were first-generation in college -- and were selected with an emphasis on providing high-caliber field research opportunities to talented students not able to find them at their home institutions.

All students presented their research at the end of their respective summers at an undergraduate symposium held on the Texas A&M campus, and they all had abstracts accepted to the American Geophysical Union Fall Meeting following their REU summer. Project funding supported conference travel and expenses, and 24 of the NSF-funded students attended AGU to present their projects there. 

Long-term outcomes for students show significant positive impacts of the program. As of March 2023, for the 28 participating students:

  • 13 have entered graduate studies;
  • 5 of these students have been awarded the prestigious NSF Graduate Research Fellowship;
  • 6 students chose to not immediately enter graduate studies, but these students have entered professional positions enhanced by their REU experience and with benefits to the public good including: environmental scientist at Natural Resources Conservation Service, environment and energy policy analyst at Tennessee Valley Authority, environmental scientist at Utah Dept. of Environmental Quality, STEM educator and founder of a non-profit, geospatial data analyst in private industry, and civil engineer in private practice; and
  • 3 students are still completing undergraduate studies.

Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the program implemented a rapid transition to a virtual/distance format in 2020. (It was one of only two REU programs that operated in summer 2020 at TAMU, which typically hosts 20-30 programs each summer). Lessons learned from this transition were shared with the REU community at the AGU Fall Meeting that year ("The 'Great Online REU Migration': Evolve Rapidly or Go Extinct" [ED035-0001]). Multiple modes of "distance research" were implemented and found to be successful and can be transferred to other programs dealing with similar circumstances or just wishing to extend outreach.

The program shared other best practices and lessons learned on the TAMU campus and with the nationwide REU network, including:

  • A Qualtrics-based online application was developed and shared freely with other REU programs. It became the default-system for TAMU programs (achieving significant cost savings) and has been adopted by at least 10 other programs nationwide.
  • The PI and Co-PI were invited by NSF to present a session at the national-level 2018 GEO REU Workshop on the program's application and selection process and how the program reported its results to highlight inclusion and diversity in student selection.
  • REU programming to encourage student cohort development in support of learning and community building was presented at the 2019 AGU Fall Meeting ("'Thinking Like a Cohort': Managing an REU for Interdisciplinarity, Inclusion, and Inauguration of Young Scholars' Communities" [ED23E-18]).
  • The PI co-organized an AGU Education session for REUs for the fall 2021 meeting ("Supporting the Well-Being of Students and Staff in STEM Professional Learning Programs During a Pandemic and Increased Racist Violence").
  • The program PI and Co-PI have led three workshops on the TAMU campus for REU programs on recruiting and selection processes to enhance diversity in student selections.

In-program assessment conducted with students during their REU summers found significant time-sequences of attitudes and emotions through the 10 week program and beyond. This preliminary data has shaped future assessment activities to better understand how students' learning and achievement are affected by these emotional sequences, and how REU programs can use mentoring and scaffolding techniques to maximize learning and self-ideation of students as successful scientists.
